abstract.p: Brooklynites are defiantly wearing their area code (718) on T-shirts; photo (S) (Pulse column)

block.p: As New Yorkers grapple with area code angst, worrying about who is worthy of (212) and who gets stuck with (646), Brooklynites are defiantly wearing their area code (718) on their chests. In recent weeks, borough pride T-shirts have become fashionable in Brooklyn's Cobble Hill, and ''718'' T-shirts, shown on models ($16, from Refinery, at 254 Smith Street), are now as much a part of the local landscape as Razor scooters and Mr. Softee. As temperatures creep downward, the store's owners, Suzanne Bagdade and Andrew Raible, are adding long-sleeved T's ($20), and next month they hope to have sweat shirts, too.

Other outlets for outer-borough-wear include Crush (244 Smith Street), which sells ''Brooklyn Rocks'' T's ($22), tanks ($19) and -- for those who prefer to keep their pride a little more private -- panties ($8.99). Tara Sylvane, Crush's owner and logo-wear designer, plans to expand soon with new Brooklyn Rock Star and I
BKLYN lines. At Lily (177 Court Street) there are tanks ($21) and T's ($25 and $28) that also blare ''BKLYN'' in the style of Donna Karan's vowel-shunning logo, DKNY.
